words.definition: A person with whom one has a bond of mutual affection.
words.etymology: Old English frēond, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vriend and German Freund, from an Indo-European root meaning ‘to love’.

words.definition: To adopt or be in a position in which one's weight is supported by one's buttocks rather than one's feet and one's back is upright.
words.etymology: Old English sittan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zitten and German sitzen, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin sedere ‘sit’.

words.definition: A domesticated ruminant animal with a thick woolly coat.
words.etymology: Old English sceap, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schaap and German Schaf.

words.definition: A small to medium-sized primate that typically has a long tail, most kinds of which live in trees in tropical countries.
words.etymology: Late 16th century: of uncertain origin; perhaps from Low German or Middle Low German (via Dutch).

words.definition: A person or animal that swims.
words.etymology: Old English swimman (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zwemmen and German schwimmen.

words.definition: Morally good, justified, or acceptable.
words.etymology: Old English riht, related to Dutch recht and German Recht, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin rectus ‘ruled, straight’.

words.definition: On or towards the side of a person or thing that is opposite to their right.
words.etymology: Old English lyft, originally meaning ‘weak’ or ‘worthless’.

words.definition: Of or at a low or relatively low temperature.
words.etymology: Old English cald, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch koud and German kalt.

words.definition: Having a high degree of heat or a high temperature.
words.etymology: Old English hāt, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch heet and German heiß.

words.definition: Of great or more than average height.
words.etymology: Middle English (in the sense ‘valiant, brave’): probably from Old English getæl ‘prompt, active’.

words.definition: Measuring a small distance from end to end.
words.etymology: Old English sceort, of Germanic origin; related to Old Norse skorta ‘lack’, Dutch schort, and German Schurz ‘apron’.

words.definition: Having little, or too little, flesh or fat.
words.etymology: Old English thynne, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dun and German dünn.

words.definition: Having a large amount of excess flesh.
words.etymology: Old English fǣttian, related to fǣtt ‘well fed’ or ‘plump’.

words.definition: At or to the far side of (something), typically so as to be hidden by it.
words.etymology: Old English behindan (adverb), bihindan (preposition), from bi ‘by’ + hindan ‘from behind’.

words.definition: Free from dirt, marks, or stains.
words.etymology: Old English clǣne ‘free from dirt or filth’, of Germanic origin.

words.definition: A continuous vertical brick or stone structure that encloses or divides an area of land.
words.etymology: Old English, from Latin vallum ‘rampart’, from vallus ‘stake’.

words.definition: Waste material; refuse or litter.
words.etymology: Late Middle English: from Anglo-Norman French rubbous; related to rubble.

words.definition: A public road in a city or town, typically with houses and buildings on one or both sides.
words.etymology: Old English strǣt, from Latin via strata ‘paved way’.

words.definition: Propel (something) with force through the air by a movement of the arm and hand.
words.etymology: Old English thrāwan ‘twist, turn’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch draaien and German drehen.

words.definition: Go or extend across or to the other side of (a path, road, stretch of water, or area).
words.etymology: Old English cros, from Old Norse kross, from Old Irish cross (influenced by Latin crux, cruc- ‘cross’).

words.definition: A regular stopping place on a public transportation route.
words.etymology: Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin statio(n-) ‘standing, standing firm’, from stare ‘to stand’.

words.definition: An area of open land, especially one planted with crops or pasture, typically bounded by hedges or fences.
words.etymology: Old English feld (also denoting a large tract of open country), of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch veld and German Feld.

words.definition: An electronic device for storing and processing data.
words.etymology: Early 17th century (denoting a person who makes calculations): from Latin computare ‘to count or sum up’.

words.definition: The seed-bearing part of a plant, consisting of reproductive organs (stamens and carpels) typically surrounded by a brightly coloured corolla (petals).
words.etymology: Middle English flour, from Old French flor, from Latin flos, flor-.

words.definition: A long-bodied marine fish with a cartilaginous skeleton, a prominent dorsal fin, and tooth-like scales.
words.etymology: Mid 16th century: probably from German Schorck, variant of Schurke ‘scoundrel’.

words.definition: A burrowing, gregarious, plant-eating mammal with long ears, long hind legs, and a short tail.
words.etymology: Late Middle English: apparently from Old French rabotte.

words.definition: A hoofed grazing or browsing animal, with branching antlers.
words.etymology: Old English dēor ‘wild animal’, which was originally used to refer to any four-legged wild beast.
